answers.author: Jill Cornett
answers.text:
City of Savannah, Mo., pop. 5050, does not have a City Engineer, nor do we currently have a contract for an independent engineer. Poses a big problem, as none of the technical personnel have degrees in anything ... only certifications. Working with Mayor and Council to move toward contracting an independent engineer for guidance, design review, and construction management.

answers.author: Eric Cline
answers.text:
The City of Alpena, MI (10,800) has a City Engineer and an Assistant City Engineer position. The CE also oversees the DPW, which also includes the park system and the Cemetery. The CE also oversees the City utilities (which are a contracted service) and the street system. The ACE also manages the City GIS system and also assists in IT. Some of this arrangement with the ACE is also based on the skill set of the individual.

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Your old neighbors in Strasburg, VA (6,500) do not have a Town Engineer. Budgeted services vary by year with project load. FY13 budget includes only $8,000 for new contracted engineering services, plus debt service for old engineering project fees. If a private project needs engineering review, zoning fees increase to cover it. Seems to work well; Judson Rex could tell you more about the outcomes.

author: David Dillner
text:
Fellow Managers:
Of you cities that are between 5,000 and 10,000 in population, how many of you have your own City Engineer? 
If you have an internal City Engineer, do you contract out any engineering services? If so, how do you determine what is contracted out and what is done in-house? How does the City Engineer position interact with the Public Works Director (i.e., subordinate to, support, etc.)?
Please also include the City Engineer's job description with your response if it is available. 
My thanks in advance.
title: City Engineering
